title: stompix
author: stompix
content: Crypto Earn Platform Haru Invest Freezes Withdrawals, Citing Service Partner Issuehttps://decrypt.co/144354/crypto-earn-platform-haru-invest-freezes-withdrawals-citing-service-partner-issueQuoteThe South Korea-based crypto earn platform Haru has halted withdrawals for a reported 80,000 users across 140 countries.Haru Invest, a South Korean digital asset management platform, suspended withdrawals from its platform citing an “issue with one of the service partners.”The firm announced Tuesday morning that the suspension was a “tough decision” taken to protect consumer funds while the firm figured out a “contingency plan to rectify the situation.”Haru offers annual yields between 12% to 25% on five cryptocurrencies in Bitcoin (BTC), Ethereum (ETH), Tether (USDT), Circle (USDC), and XRP (XRP).https://haruinvest.com/blog/statement/QuoteWe regret that several media articles on this topic contained information that are factually inaccurate. In particular, we like to ensure our investors that claims about “Rug Pull” mentioned in some reports are not true at all. We are now fully working on the matter, and committed to protecting our investors. We will provide you with further updates as soon as it’s available.Meanwhile it seems they have deleted their Linkedin and YT profiles  Seems like we might have a small chain effect in SK since another lending platform has paused withdrawalshttps://cointelegraph.com/news/south-korean-bitcoin-lending-platform-delio-pauses-withdrawalsQuoteFounded in 2018, Delio reportedly holds an estimated $1 billion in Bitcoin , $200 million in Ether and approximately $8.1 billion in altcoins, data from its website revealed. Should I add the not your keys, not your coins stop chasing 25% APY offers line? Not that people learn or are even willing to!

comments.author: PX-Z
comments.body: 25% really is so huge return, how the hell a business can earn from such liabilities to their users when the market is not so stable. Or its just a marketing strategy? Well, no they suffer the cons (same as others) of having such business on this space.

comments.author: o_e_l_e_o
comments.body: Quote from: PX-Z on June 14, 2023, 11:54:32 PM25% really is so huge return, how the hell a business can earn from such liabilities to their users when the market is not so stable.The same as every other such platform which has collapsed over the past few months. They take your money and make hugely risky investments, loans, or bets. They take almost all the profits for themselves, and when it inevitably goes to shit it is the users who are left with nothing with the CEO and buddies all walk away with millions in the bank.Look at FTX, Celsius, Voyager, BlockFi, etc. Same story every time.

comments.author: yhiaali3
comments.body: Quote from: stompix on June 16, 2023, 08:12:02 AMIt's a platform where you earn numbers on a screen while you lose bitcoins!Yes, this is the correct description of the problem. Unfortunately, people love these large numbers on the screen that are constantly growing, but in the end they wake up to an illusion and catch nothing in their pockets. Only then do they regret and realize the value of Bitcoin.This is not the first time and it certainly won't be the last, despite hundreds of completely similar incidents, every time the same story and the same scenario are repeated and people never learn, even if they learn greed draws them into a trap.

comments.author: arbiter5
comments.body: Always use custodial platforms with the assumption that they will one day freeze withdrawals. Always keep your funds deposited at a minimum.

comments.author: Husires
comments.body: In the past, they were a little clever, as they gave you high returns from a token, and when they could not pay, they reduced the value of the token.The higher the platform gives APY, the greater the risk of bankruptcy, and on average, any platform that gives APY higher than the average of what banks in your region offer is a platform that may go bankrupt during the next two years, not to mention returns of 13% for all users in a market where there are no institutions that guarantee You get your money back if any problem happens. these things should be indicators to move away from these platforms and not to increase investment in them.

comments.author: LTU_btc
comments.body: Never heard about this platform before, but in general - nothing surprising to read these news. In recent months we heard so many similar stories about investing platforms falling down and I have no doubts that's not last one.Up to 25% APY, c'mon, you can't be serious if you believe in it. Fancy looking investment platform, but in reality, it's not much different from cheap ponzi schemes that is promoted here on Invest based games board. It seems that people will never learn that you can get easy money without doing anything.

comments.author: Free Market Capitalist
comments.body: Quote from: LTU_btc on June 18, 2023, 11:16:08 PMUp to 25% APY, c'mon, you can't be serious if you believe in it. In general, if we were talking about fiat, just by the percentage alone we would know it was a scam. As the crypto world has had much higher returns, higher percentages did not scream scam in the beginning but we should use the same criteria: anyone who pretends to guarantee you a return of more than 10% per year, is either trying to scam you or does not know what he is doing.And if we take into account that by lending Bitcoin you lose control of it, we will come to the conclusion that it is never worth doing it for a supposedly small extra % of profitability.

comments.author: Z-tight
comments.body: Quote from: tabas on June 15, 2023, 09:09:24 PMThat seems where it is going and if there have been a bunch of people deposited it there and have been attracted to what they're offering, that's sad to say that they have to be prepared mentally before hearing the announcement about those pending withdrawals and current deposits that are in there. People are attracted to the APY that they are offering without considering the risks of giving away the custody of their funds, once a platform or exchange can freeze or withhold the withdrawal of your coins, it is obvious that you do not own those coins, because whoever owns the funds should be able to withdraw or spend it anytime that they want to do so, not when it is made available to them.

comments.author: crwth
comments.body: It is not mathematically correct to do that 25% yield. It's something to entice users to deposit more so that they could pay more than the investors they have. It's not always going to be a sure thing to have, and imagine having that "too good to be true" aspect is already a red flag. Better store your coins in a wallet that you can control.
